messageBody:
Cedric,

Appreciate your reference to "migration" as one of the (cost)
components of technology change.

When performing a cost/benefit analysis the availability of a
thoughtful (well-engineered) migration strategy certainly helps
reduce the "cost". (It would not be considered a benefit - since
migration is fundamentally a "cost" component.)

Another often overlooked cost component is "legal". It was
interesting to consult at one recent company and note they
considered themselves indemnified for using JDK 1.3 by virtue of its
distribution with their licensed Application Server and IDE
environment. In other words, you were not authorized to use a v.
1.3 JDK other than the one distributed with the licensed IDE
installed by their infrastructure support team on your desktop.

(Note: The same was true for JUnit and Struts. Since JUnit/Struts
was distributed by the licensed vendor with the IDE it could be
used. No upgrades allowed!)

*** End of Response *** ... Opinions follow.

While thinking more about JavaDoc annotations; it seems (to me)
there is a fundamental contextual difference between using an
annotation as a "marker" (@deprecated with JDK or @excludeClass with
TestUtil) to be interpreted outside of method invocation and using a
JavaDoc annotation to alter runtime execution. (This might be
considered similar to the distinction between using an Interface as
a loosely-coupled marker [to overcome single-class inheritance] vs.
an Interface to force tight [fragile] coupling between artifacts.)

So - what I'm having trouble cost justifying is introducing a
runtime influencing technology that simply is a stylistic
programming change - from "test" to "@Test". There is no value-add
here. Right? No additional value to customers and no additional
value to developers. It is simply style.

Or, am I fundamentally missing something.

_Marvin
